page.title: 04Llangunllo language
page.content: The{Language}of Llangunllo's old established residents has some distinctive features which reflect the village's proximity to the{Anglo-Welsh {border. }Thus the many {dialect} words used (e.g. 'oouty-tumps' or mole hills;'to glut a hedge with trouse'or fill a hole with dry material) are generally of Anglo-Saxon origin: as is the use of the 'strong past'('shore' for 'sheared';'puck'for'picked.) But Welsh, though not spoken within living memory, has influenced sentence construction (for example,'the sheep are in the field all') and, perhaps the frequent use of personal pronouns for inanimate objects('tush him out' for 'heave it out'). Common too are dialectical contractions, 'conner, wunner, dunner': and many {archaic {forms}such as "It wunner affect we" (It won't affect us).
